GHOST APPLES  

After freezing rain in Michigan, apples that hadn’t been picked got coated in ice. Many fell off the tree. Some had their insides turn to mush as apples have lower freezing points. The mush and skin fell, leaving these “ghost apples.” 

: Andrew Sietsemapic.twitter.com/MWKUUv43aI

1125741027447513088.text: That made me think that AR is just as likely to be detrimental for workers because it makes human labor more exchangeable. It puts power in the hands of factory owners (who will own the AR Smart Goggles) and make lower-skilled laborers easier to fire.

1125740612295307264.text: I was curious they named AR as a positive variety of new tech, because it can theoretically help lower-skilled laborers move into higher-skills positions without expensive/time-consuming retraining (because your AR smart goggles will tell you what to do in the factory)

1105150654799065090.text:
Where does that leave academia? Is cutting-edge AI research only the domain of billion-dollar companies? Get in my DMs if you've got an opinion on this... 

And a last thought: can AGI — which some believe will be humanity's 'last invention' — be created without capitalism?

1105150251311206401.text: Remember, even as a nonprofit OAI was able to pay top researchers huge salaries (one got $1.9 million in a single year), yet they're sending the message that to do the work they want to (develop AGI) they need *billions* more.

1105149882132774912.text:
Key points: 
- OAI says change is necessary to attract billions of $ for "large-scale cloud compute" and salaries
- OAI says the corporate structure means their goal of developing AGI safely always comes first (see purple box below)
-  Current research goals do not changepic.twitter.com/72oumA5dre

1105149085680586752.text: very very interesting news from OpenAI. They're no longer a nonprofit but a "capped-profit" company. First round investors could receive up to 100 x their initial investment if and when the company starts making moneyhttps://openai.com/blog/openai-lp/

1104069922110484481.text: The end result is certainly more flexible and surprising and, just, better. But DeepBlue's steam hammer intelligence was surely just as alien to Kasparov? Humans don't need to be out-thought to be outmatched.

1104069481205243905.text: Bridle distinguishes between AlphaGo's "intuition" and DeepBlue's "brute-force" approach to symbolize the stepchange in AI. But AlphaGo is as much a product of brute force thinking (reinforcement learning at a gigantic scale) as DeepBlue ever was.

1104068952962097153.text: I agree that it feels like a shift in our understanding of intelligence is coming, but I don't think there is necessarily a technological trigger here — I think it's cultural.

1103994670697377793.text:
It's called Beyond Measure and will be published by @FaberBooks.

Suggestions that I might call it "Absolute Unit" were swiftly vetoed.

1103994451175845888.text: Expect to learn about the peninkulma (an old Finnish unit that's the distance a dog barks), about the US anti-metric movement of the 19th century (who believed the Inch was handed down from God via the pyramids), and how standardized measures are used and abused by state powers

1103993229958094848.text: If you enjoyed my reporting on the redefinition of the kilogram last year, you might like this too. 1103625498419216385.text: turns out the algorithm is reusing the visual data it knows about steam trains to identify the air tanks used by divers. After all, both are round, shiny, metal objects. Researchers proved this by adding pics of locomotives to snorkelers to flip the classification to scuba diver!pic.twitter.com/Hme8KD0NWB

1103625298157993985.text: My favorite example of this is spotting the difference between "snorkel" and "scuba diver." This graph shows the visual data used for classifying both images, but why on earth does the classification for scuba diver involve visual data about locomotives? (bottom right)pic.twitter.com/2MOP2ekTYf

1103600694253232129.text: Original paper suggested 'prenatal hormone theory' was the mechanism at work - hormones in the womb influencing face shape and sexuality. Critics said culture/lifestyle influences (eg grooming/fashion) were more likely predictors; this supports the latter analysis

1097211590988976128.text:
Key question seems to be whether or not the full model would be a ‘threat’?

I’ve seen lots of people saying the gpt-2 got outsized attention/scares relative to its technical novelty, but less response to the idea that maybe models like this could cause harm if widely accessible

1097208924992950272.text: One thing I’ve wondered is to what degree journalists coverage was shaped by us feeling this work more personally given our profession

1096324952607862784.text: Following the publication of OpenAI's GPT-2 yesterday, there's been some great discussion in the AI community over the rights/wrongs of their publication approach. Good thread on it (and thread within this thread) herehttps://twitter.com/deliprao/status/1096219405506080768 …

1096100016240893953.text: Anyway, because it's Valentine's Day, here's a little poem written by GPT-2.pic.twitter.com/r97JS6t8H1

1096099818215276544.text: Despite its shortcomings, playing around with this system was the most excited I've been by AI for a while. You could put this down to my lack of technical nous — this is very accessible — but it's hard not to dream of AI systems that read, analyze, answer with superhuman speed.

1096098249918812161.text:
Important to note that it's much *worse* at these tasks than specialized systems. The impressive thing is it learned them without prompting. 

The question is: how far can this approach be pushed? Can you create a reliable multi-talented AI just be having it read the internet?

1096097810758418438.text: The killer feature here is that it learned (very badly) how to perform tasks it wasn't trained on. These include translations, summaries, and answering trivia. In each case you have to structure your request. In the translation example providing sample pairs of phrasespic.twitter.com/aZztsYgTPD

1096097392619909123.text: Here are some samples from the system... I supplied the first line and the algorithm has written everything underlined. You can see how it matches tonal cues in the language — writing a news story in the first example, and Lord of the Rings fanfic in the secondpic.twitter.com/NnKfPFN6CB

1096095114370473984.text:
OpenAI has created a new AI language modeling system and it is *wild*

It was trained on a dataset of 8 million webpages, and without specialized tooling can not only generate text but translate, summarize, and answer trivia questions...

Details here:https://www.theverge.com/2019/2/14/18224704/ai-machine-learning-language-models-read-write-openai-gpt2 …

1095361585105776640.text:
The hagfish is a paean to the effectiveness of being soft.

Its slime is weaponised intangibility; its absent backbone and baggy skin let it shrug off shark bites; and it doesn’t even need teeth to feed, absorbing nutrients through its skin insteadhttps://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2019/01/hagfish-slime/581002/ …

1093860915391414272.text: Social media platforms have created this data and algorithms are making it easier to process. Health insurance is just one place it might be used, of course — job recruiters and employers are also digging in

Insurance companies in the US are starting to use information posted online to calculate premiums
